isis.stitle: Recall 00506 - Re-orienting the Air Operated Brake and Cruise Control Switches in 5000/5000i and 9000/9000i Model Series Vehicles Built 07/01/1998 Through 07/02/2000

recall.subject: Re-orienting the Air Operated Brake and Cruise Control Switches in 5000/5000i and 9000/9000i Model Series Vehicles Built 07/01/1998 Through 07/02/2000

defect.para: The brake light switch and the cruise control switch are mounted in such a way as to allow moisture within the air brake system to collect inside the switches. Moisture collection within the switches can cause the switches to fail prematurely and when the outside temperature drops below freezing the risk of failure increases. Moisture in the brake light switch can result in no brake lights to warn other vehicles. Moisture in the cruise control switch can result in an extended stopping distance if the cruise control does not disengage as expected when the brake pedal is pressed. Either one of these switch failure modes can cause the vehicle to be involved in an accident which may result in property damage, personal injury, or death.
This Safety Recall includes all 5000, 5000i, 9000, and 9000i model series built 07/01/1998 through 07/02/2000.

ownernote.para: International Truck and Engine Corporation will notify owners of these vehicles about this campaign. During the recall process, a listing of owner names and addresses will be furnished to the involved dealers to enable dealers to follow up with owners and have the vehicles corrected. You must limit the use of this listing to this campaign since the list may contain information obtained from state motor vehicle registration records and the use of such motor vehicle registration data for purposes other than this campaign is a violation of law in several states.

svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE
svcproc.para: Description: This procedure explains how to re-orient or remount the air switch manifold on the engine side of the dash panel to the position shown below in Figure 1.

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. Brake switch has red stripe on switch body (orange wire).
2. Cruise control switch has white stripe on switch body (purple wire).
3. Brake switch and cruise control switch wires should be tie strapped to the air manifold here.

step1.para: Park the vehicle on level ground, set the parking brake and shut off the engine.

warning.para: Block the wheels to prevent the vehicle from moving. If the vehicle rolls unexpectedly, the result could be serious personal injury or death.

step1.para: Unplug the electrical connectors from the brake and cruise switches and remove the switches from the air manifold. Gently shake the switches with the port end down to remove any collected moisture.
Remove the 1/4 inch yellow brake tube(s) at the air manifold. There will be two air lines to remove if the vehicle has an air application gauge.

Remove the left most gauge panel to see if there are any fasteners or wires attached to the end of the bolt on the inside of the cab and remove any fasteners that may be attached to the air manifold mounting bolt. If there are no fasteners attached to the end of the bolt, you can re-install the gauge panel.

Remove the air manifold mounting bolt from the engine side of the dash panel and remove the air manifold. Gently shake the manifold, with the ports pointing downward, to remove any collected moisture.
Using the manifold mounting bolt, attach the extension clip in the original mounting hole in the dash panel as shown below in Figure 2 and tighten the bolt.

Using a 1/4 inch nut (PN: 25402R1) and lockwasher (PN: 120380), remount the air manifold to the extension clip stud so the switches are pointing upward as shown in Figure 1. Tighten the 1/4 inch nut on the bracket stud.

Reconnect the air line(s): remove the plug from the inboard vertical port and install it in the inboard end port and re-install the inboard air hose into the most inboard vertical port. If the hose is too short, cut a 13 inch piece to replace it (PN: 3528470C1). Re-install the air application gauge hose, if vehicle is so equipped, into the most outboard end port of the air manifold.

Re-install the switches and reconnect the switch wires. The installation of the brake light and cruise control switch wires will require extra wire length which may be obtained by carefully opening the end of the wire harness and pulling out the extra wire length that was tucked into the harness at the factory.
Reseal the end of the wire harness with electrical tape.

Connect the orange wire to the switch with the red stripe on it and connect the purple wire to the switch with the white stripe on it and tie strap the switch wires to the air manifold (see tie strap location, Item 3, Figure 1). If the wires are still too short, relocate the switches to a closer port to gain slack.

Check the brake lights to make sure they come on when the brake pedal is pressed. If the brake lights do not come on, the wires of the cruise and brake switch may be reversed. Do not replace a switch unless it is defective.
Re-install the fasteners that were removed from the mounting bolt in Step 5 and re-install the gauge panel. This completes the service procedure.

para.emph: * You will need the following parts for every vehicle in this campaign:

partsinfo.para: 1. One extension clip/bracket for each vehicle, PN: 3553487C1.
2. One 1/4 inch-20 nut used on the stud on the bracket above, PN: 25402R1.
3. One 1/4 inch lockwasher used on the stud on the bracket above, PN: 120380.

para.emph: * You may also need these additional parts:

partsinfo.para: 1. Hose: Some vehicles may require 13 inches of PN: 3528470C1.

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified IMMEDIATELY from your dealer location.
Dealers must correct all vehicles subject to this campaign at no charge to the owner, regardless of mileage, age of vehicle, or ownership, from this time forward.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.
However, consistent with the customer notification, dealers are expected to complete the repairs on the mutually agreed upon service date.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his or her vehicle as soon as possible.
